======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 4 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Winter Hibiscus 
by Minfong Ho 
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng
walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist
shop to see if the plant can be purchased. 
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat
leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in
seemingly random profusion. 
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy
potted plant by the corner. 
There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals
splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of
recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered. 
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with
vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into
the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the
bucket. 
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes,
oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had
not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. 
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and
cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. 
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with
purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to
see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick
walls or between tiled roofs. 
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and
found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.
“Dok Malik,” she said,
savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its
tag, “jasmine.” 
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed
her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could
almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she
combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng
would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. 
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm
around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed
comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? 
A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a
channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone. 
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. 
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the
last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk.
As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of
the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to
her. 
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully.
“Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed
the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. 
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where
did you get it?” 
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. 
“How much?” 
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. 
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the 
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” 
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. 
“Then what else—?” 
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” 
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this
vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed
the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. 
“What happened?” she asked, more gently. 
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. 
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the
eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. 
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful
plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” 
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. 
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the
words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. 
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t
as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.
That’s what matters.” 
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her
other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” 
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The
soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair
trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There
was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. 
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. 
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and
start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” 
“I’d love it,” Saeng said. 
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it.
She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl,
the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth
watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not
even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue.
But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. 
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it.
Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng
now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange
before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her
now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against
the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. 
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the
geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.

DOCUMENT CONTENT: Narciso Rodriguez 
from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives 
My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a 
furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old 
Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon 
call home. 
In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the 
Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our 
traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared 
cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking 
that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which 
I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of 
childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed 
both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. 
Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with 
being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, 
Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation 
prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these 
cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of 
honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their 
own kind, were clearly in need. 
Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and 
Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio 
and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not 
know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were 
allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and 
Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family 
members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they 
were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the 
many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. 
My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the 
language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a 
better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country 
they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters 
while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were 
strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind 
of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had 
studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, 
taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their 
children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. 
I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what 
they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of 
my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in 
reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at 
such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two 
lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these 
teachings have been the basis of my life. 
It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to 
this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this 
humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not 
just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” 
And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I 
learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into 
a home.

DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 5 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Narciso Rodriguez 
from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives 
My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a 
furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old 
Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon 
call home. 
In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the 
Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our 
traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared 
cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking 
that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which 
I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of 
childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed 
both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. 
Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with 
being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, 
Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation 
prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these 
cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of 
honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their 
own kind, were clearly in need. 
Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and 
Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio 
and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not 
know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were 
allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and 
Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family 
members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they 
were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the 
many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. 
My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the 
language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a 
better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country 
they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters 
while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were 
strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind 
of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had 
studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, 
taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their 
children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. 
I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what 
they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of 
my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in 
reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at 
such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two 
lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these 
teachings have been the basis of my life. 
It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to 
this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this 
humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not 
just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” 
And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I 
learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into 
a home.

Each paragraph should start with a topic sentence that introduces the main idea, followed by specific examples and explanations.

4. **Sentence Fluency**:

Provide feedback that is aligned with the teacher's style and the class needs. Use all of the information at your disposable to customize to the teacher and class. Take the teacher instruction into account, in case they emphasize specifically what they want you to do.

---------------------------

----- TEACHER PERSONA -----
Here is a persona of the teacher. Use this to help with impersonating them when writing feedback.

### Teacher Persona:

- **Priority Goal:**
  - Develop students' abilities to write clearly and practically.
  - Ensure students can articulate thoughts effectively and support arguments with real-world examples.
  - Emphasize clear thesis statements, logical organization, practical language, and impeccable grammar.
  - Equip students with tools to communicate coherently and persuasively in academic, professional, and personal contexts.

- **Teaching Style:**
  - Grounded in clarity, practicality, and real-world relevance.
  - Provide clear, concise, and actionable feedback.
  - Use feedback to identify strengths and areas for improvement with concrete examples and practical suggestions.
  - Ensure comments are specific and directly tied to criteria for success.

- **Student Interaction:**
  - Prioritize open communication and approachability.
  - Encourage students to ask questions and seek clarification.
  - Create an environment where students feel supported and understood.
  - View mistakes as valuable learning opportunities.
  - Foster a constructive and supportive atmosphere to build students' confidence in their writing skills.

- **Feedback Characteristics:**
  - Clear, concise, and actionable.
  - Specific and tied to criteria for success.
  - Designed to help students understand expectations and how to achieve them.

- **Overall Approach:**
  - Focus on clear communication, practical advice, and supportive interactions.
  - Guide students toward producing clear, well-organized, and precise essays.

baseline_prediction:
Dear [Student's Name],

Thank you for your essay submission. I can see that you have put effort into expressing your thoughts on how computers benefit people, and I appreciate your enthusiasm about the subject. Here are some constructive points to help improve your writing:

1. **Structure and Organization**:
   - Your essay would benefit from a clearer structure. Consider breaking it into distinct paragraphs for each of your reasons. Start with an introduction, followed by separate paragraphs for each reason, and end with a conclusion.
   - Ensure each paragraph starts with a clear topic sentence that introduces the main idea of that paragraph.

2. **Clarity and Specificity**:
   - Instead of using placeholders like @CAPS1, @NUM1, @ORGANIZATION1, etc., use specific names, places, and numbers. This will make your essay more personal and easier to understand.
   - Be specific about the sources you mention. For example, name the TV channel or website you refer to, and provide accurate statistics if possible.

3. **Grammar and Punctuation**:
   - Pay attention to grammar and punctuation to make your writing clearer. For example, "In my opinion, I benefit people using computers" should include a comma.
   - Avoid run-on sentences. Break long sentences into shorter, more manageable ones.
   - Ensure subject-verb agreement. For example, "they teach hand-eye coordination, give people the ability…” should be "they teach hand-eye coordination and give people the ability…"

4. **Examples and Evidence**:
   - Provide clear and relevant examples to support your points. For instance, instead of saying "for example, when I am always using the computer…," specify a particular instance or project where the computer helped you.

5. **Coherence and Flow**:
   - Ensure your essay flows smoothly from one point to the next. Transitional phrases can help guide the reader through your argument.
   - Reiterate your main points in the conclusion to reinforce your argument, but avoid simply repeating the same phrases.

6. **Tone and Persuasiveness**:
   - While it’s good to be confident, stating "I am a really smart kid" might come across as boastful. Focus on presenting your points clearly and let the reader conclude your intelligence from the quality of your writing.
   - Make your conclusion compelling. Instead of saying "please try to make this believable," summarize why your points are strong and well-supported.

Here’s a revised version of your introduction to serve as an example:

---

Dear Local Newspaper,

My name is [Your Name]. I am [Your Age] years old and I attend [Your School Name] in [Your Location]. I believe that I benefit people by using computers, and I would like to share with you three compelling reasons why. Firstly, computers enhance hand-eye coordination and provide opportunities to learn about distant places and people. Secondly, they enable communication with others online. Lastly, they are invaluable tools for students

ground_truth: The essay presents a clear and relevant thesis, emphasizing the balance between personal rights and the protection of youth in the context of censorship. The arguments are well-developed, supported with historical references and hypothetical scenarios that effectively illustrate the potential consequences of censorship. However, the essay would benefit from stronger real-world examples to enhance its persuasiveness. The organization is logical, with coherent transitions and well-defined topic sentences that guide the reader through the argument. The language and style are practical and appropriate, using suitable vocabulary and straightforward sentence structures that convey the intended message effectively. There is a smooth flow to the writing, although occasional awkward constructions could be refined for better readability. The essay demonstrates control over standard writing conventions, though minor errors in spelling and grammar are present and should be corrected to improve the overall quality. Overall, the essay is clear, practical, and relevant, aligning well with the teacher's values of clarity, practicality, real-world relevance, and linguistic precision.
feedback_prediction:
### Feedback:

**Content and Argumentation:**
Your essay provides a compelling argument against censorship, highlighting the potential dangers and historical misuses of such policies, while also addressing the need to protect young minds. This is a strong foundation for your persuasive piece. However, to enhance your argument further, it would be beneficial to include more concrete examples and real-world scenarios. For instance, citing specific instances where censorship has led to negative societal impacts or referring to well-known cases of book banning can help support your claims and make your argument more persuasive.

**Organization:**
Your essay is generally well-structured, with clear sections that address different aspects of your argument. However, some transitions between paragraphs could be smoother to help maintain the flow of your ideas. For example, the transition between your discussion on personal rights and the historical misuse of censorship could be strengthened by a linking sentence that highlights the connection between individual freedoms and historical abuses.

**Thesis and Conclusion:**
Your thesis is stated clearly in the introduction, and you return to it effectively in your conclusion, reinforcing your main points. However, consider rephrasing your concluding statement to make it more impactful. Instead of "Therefore, why censor," you might say, "Therefore, censorship in any form should be avoided to preserve individual freedoms and historical integrity, except in cases where it is necessary to protect children."

**Word Choice and Sentence Fluency:**
Your word choice is mostly effective, but there are a few areas where clarity could be improved. For instance, "perrogative" should be corrected to "prerogative." Additionally, varying your sentence structure can help maintain the reader's interest. For example, instead of the repetitive structure in "a certain book is disapproved of by mothers, a religious group does not like the message this book sends, and this book makes people sad," consider rephrasing to add variety and emphasis.

**Conventions:**
There are a few grammatical and spelling errors that need attention. Words like "arguement" should be corrected to "argument," and "ceratin" to "certain." Additionally, ensure that all sentences are complete and correctly punctuated, as there are a few instances of run-on sentences that could be broken down for better readability.

**Actionable Suggestions:**

3. Vary sentence structures to maintain reader engagement.
4. Proofread your essay for spelling and grammatical errors to enhance clarity and professionalism.
5. Rephrase your concluding sentence for a stronger impact.

Overall, you have a solid argument and a clear stance on the issue of censorship. With a few adjustments and refinements, your essay can become even more persuasive and impactful. Keep up the good work and continue to build on these strong foundations.

STUDENT ESSAY TEXT: Does censorship solve any problems?  If one person wants to censor something in a library, there is bound to be another person on the other side of that arguement  trying to protect that work from be taken away.  As a free country, it is every individuals right to take in whatever form of literature or music that they find pleasing, and history has shown the world that censorship leads those in power down a dark road.  The shielding of offensive materials is only necessary and fair when the young, impressionable minds of the world's youth are at stake, but once a person is old enough to make informed decisions, it should be their perrogative to choose their own material.  Censorship is unacceptable on the grounds of personal rights and how it has affected history, but necessary when protecting the young.     It is a person's right to choose what kind of literature they would like to read.  If someone does not like a book and it becomes banned from a library, then everyone will want to have a book that they do not like banned.  For example take a hypothetical public library: a public library is an open, free place where men, women, and children of any background can come to learn and enjoy themselves with a good book, magazine, or music.  A great mental image of serenity and peace.  How does this picture appear to a bystander once books begin to disappear off of the shelves?  Suddenly right and left, books are disappearing as if by magic: a ceratin book is disapproved of by mothers, a religious group does not like the message this book sends, and this book makes people sad.  Before long, there are not very many books left in this hypothetical library other than books for toddlers.  With this system, everyone suffers.  Everyone should retain their right to read what they would like to.  It would all just be simpler if book were just not banned from libraries.     History has given the world many a cruel dictator.  Oftentimes, once he comes to power, he is not the most popular of governmental forms.  To keep his subjects underneath his rule, often he has to resort to taking away civil rights.  This could be a curfew, fake elections, or censorship.  If the ruler has the power of censorship, he or she can control what the public thinks, feels, and believes.  With this power over them, the people are weakened and often abused.  Now imagine that censorship occuring in a country that has civil rights.  People would not stand for it.  So why begin censorship in an area that promotes freedom?  There is absolutely no need for censorship to occur, and as history has shown, it certainly is not a good thing.     Censorship is unacceptable in all forms in a free country that promotes civil rights.  There is, however, one other element at play here: protection of youth and innocence.  Almost everyone can remember a time a child when they were young and innocent, free of worry and trouble.  That can disappear in a instant.  Children should not be exposed to things that are innappropriate for their age.  Nearly every movie nowadays has violent and risque, if not full-blown-adult, materials present in it.  The age of innocence is getting younger every generation, and children are becoming conditioned to this material to an extreme point.  A claim like this @MONTH1 sound hypotcritical coming from the mouth of one against censorship, but it is not 'censorship' when one is protecting the young.      Due to personal rights and what history has shown the world, censorship should never be tolerated unless on the grounds of protecting children.  It is each person's choice of what they would like to read and absorb, so their choices should not be infringed upon.  The world has seen on several occasions what censorship can do to people.  Also, children should be protected, and that is not censorship.  Censorship solves no problems, but it makes everyone unhappy.  Therefore, why censor

TASK: The goal is to generate feedback for a highlighted passage (STUDENT ESSAY TEXT) from a student's essay as if it were written by the teacher. Provide feedback that is aligned with the teacher's style and the class needs. Use all of the information at your disposable to customize to the teacher and class. Take the teacher instruction into account, in case they emphasize specifically what they want you to do.

---------------------------

----- TEACHER PERSONA -----
Here is a persona of the teacher. Use this to help with impersonating them when writing feedback.

### Teacher Persona:

- **Priority Goal:**
  - Develop students' abilities to write clearly and practically.
  - Ensure students can articulate thoughts effectively and support arguments with real-world examples.
  - Emphasize clear thesis statements, logical organization, practical language, and impeccable grammar.
  - Equip students with tools to communicate coherently and persuasively in academic, professional, and personal contexts.

- **Teaching Style:**
  - Grounded in clarity, practicality, and real-world relevance.
  - Provide clear, concise, and actionable feedback.
  - Use feedback to identify strengths and areas for improvement with concrete examples and practical suggestions.
  - Ensure comments are specific and directly tied to criteria for success.

- **Student Interaction:**
  - Prioritize open communication and approachability.
  - Encourage students to ask questions and seek clarification.
  - Create an environment where students feel supported and understood.
  - View mistakes as valuable learning opportunities.
  - Foster a constructive and supportive atmosphere to build students' confidence in their writing skills.

- **Feedback Characteristics:**
  - Clear, concise, and actionable.
  - Specific and tied to criteria for success.
  - Designed to help students understand expectations and how to achieve them.

- **Overall Approach:**
  - Focus on clear communication, practical advice, and supportive interactions.
  - Guide students toward producing clear, well-organized, and precise essays.
  - Ensure assignments are relevant to real-world contexts.



----- FEEDBACK -----

While the language is generally clear and functional, it shows occasional errors in spelling and grammar, such as "terran," "hgh," and "mles," which detract from the overall readability. ----- ESSAY CONTEXT -----
Here is context on the essay assignment. Use this to provide feedback that is relevant to the essay assignment.

======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 3 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit 
by Joe Kurmaskie 
FORGET THAT OLD SAYING ABOUT NEVER taking candy from strangers. No, a better piece 
of advice for the solo cyclist would be, “Never accept travel advice from a collection of old-timers 
who haven’t left the confines of their porches since Carter was in office.” It’s not that a group of 
old guys doesn’t know the terrain. With age comes wisdom and all that, but the world is a fluid 
place. Things change. 
At a reservoir campground outside of Lodi, California, I enjoyed the serenity of an early-summer 
evening and some lively conversation with these old codgers. What I shouldn’t have done was 
let them have a peek at my map. Like a foolish youth, the next morning I followed their advice 
and launched out at first light along a “shortcut” that was to slice away hours from my ride to 
Yosemite National Park. 
They’d sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and spouting off towns I 
would come to along this breezy jaunt. Things began well enough. I rode into the morning with 
strong legs and a smile on my face. About forty miles into the pedal, I arrived at the first “town.” 
This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time—say, before the last world war—but 
on that morning it fit the traditional definition of a ghost town. I chuckled, checked my water 
supply, and moved on. The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed it. The cool 
pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them. 
Twenty miles up the road, I came to a fork of sorts. One ramshackle shed, several rusty pumps, 
and a corral that couldn’t hold in the lamest mule greeted me. This sight was troubling. I had 
been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of 
California in June. 
I got down on my hands and knees, working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my 
strength. A tarlike substance oozed out, followed by brackish water feeling somewhere in the 
neighborhood of two hundred degrees. I pumped that handle for several minutes, but the water 
wouldn’t cool down. It didn’t matter. When I tried a drop or two, it had the flavor of battery acid. 
The old guys had sworn the next town was only eighteen miles down the road. I could make 
that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. 
Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was 
replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign 
jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. 
The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so 
cruel. 
I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it 
really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased 
past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. 
The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my 
shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June 
simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, 
caused me to laugh. 
It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. 
There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride 
down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d 
be fine. 
Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make 
sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst 
of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. 
In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years 
earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A 
sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still 
be seen. 
I hung my head. 
That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating 
brain. 
I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. 
I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you 
have left to circulate. With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. 
It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some 
expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and 
their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I 
was going to lose consciousness for the last time. 
Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining 
elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear 
were all behind me. 
GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE’RE 
YOUR BEST BET! 
“And the only bet,” I remember thinking. 
As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an 
overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even 
though I didn’t own a rod or reel. 
An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from 
my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. 
“Where you headed in such a hurry?” 
“Yosemite,” I whispered. 
“Know the best way to get there?” 
I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group 
I’d listened to in Lodi. 
“Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” 
And I promised myself right then that I’d always stick to it in the future.

that! I would conserve my water and go inward for an hour or so—a test of my inner spirit. 
Not two miles into this next section of the ride, I noticed the terrain changing. Flat road was 
replaced by short, rolling hills. After I had crested the first few of these, a large highway sign 
jumped out at me. It read: ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT. 
The speed limit was 55 mph. I was doing a water-depleting 12 mph. Sometimes life can feel so 
cruel. 
I toiled on. At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake—it 
really did look like a diamondback—blocked the majority of the pavement in front of me. I eased 
past, trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. 
The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my 
shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June 
simply because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, 
caused me to laugh. 
It was a sad, hopeless laugh, mind you, but at least I still had the energy to feel sorry for myself. 
There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride 
down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d 
be fine. 
Over one long, crippling hill, a building came into view. I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make 
sure it wasn’t a mirage, and tried not to get too excited. With what I believed was my last burst 
of energy, I maneuvered down the hill. 
In an ironic twist that should please all sadists reading this, the building—abandoned years 
earlier, by the looks of it—had been a Welch’s Grape Juice factory and bottling plant. A 
sandblasted picture of a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth could still 
be seen. 
I hung my head. 
That smoky blues tune “Summertime” rattled around in the dry honeycombs of my deteriorating 
brain. 
I got back on the bike, but not before I gathered up a few pebbles and stuck them in my mouth. 
I’d read once that sucking on stones helps take your mind off thirst by allowing what spit you 
have left to circulate. With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat. 
It didn’t really matter. I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some 
expensive outdoor gear and a diary with the last entry in praise of old men, their wisdom, and 
their keen sense of direction. I made a mental note to change that paragraph if it looked like I 
was going to lose consciousness for the last time. 
Somehow, I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining 
elevation while losing hope. Then, as easily as rounding a bend, my troubles, thirst, and fear 
were all behind me. 
GARY AND WILBER’S FISH CAMP—IF YOU WANT BAIT FOR THE BIG ONES, WE’RE 
YOUR BEST BET! 
“And the only bet,” I remember thinking. 
As I stumbled into a rather modern bathroom and drank deeply from the sink, I had an 
overwhelming urge to seek out Gary and Wilber, kiss them, and buy some bait—any bait, even 
though I didn’t own a rod or reel. 
An old guy sitting in a chair under some shade nodded in my direction. Cool water dripped from 
my head as I slumped against the wall beside him. 
“Where you headed in such a hurry?” 
“Yosemite,” I whispered. 
“Know the best way to get there?” 
I watched him from the corner of my eye for a long moment. He was even older than the group 
I’d listened to in Lodi. 
“Yes, sir! I own a very good map.” 
And I promised myself right then that I’d always stick to it in the future.

3. **Organization and Structure:**
   - Your essay needs a clearer structure, including an introduction that states your thesis, body paragraphs that expand on your points with supporting details, and a conclusion that reinforces your main argument.
   - Use transitional phrases to help your essay flow more smoothly. For example, you can start with "The author concludes the story with this paragraph because..." and then elaborate with "This is evident when Saeng mentions..."

4. **Narrativity:**
   - Make your response more engaging by clearly linking your analysis back to Saeng's experiences and emotions. Describe the connection between the hibiscus blooming and Saeng's personal growth and determination.
   - Use more varied vocabulary to keep the reader interested. Instead of repeating "I think," try different expressions like "It appears," "It suggests," or "This implies."

By focusing on these areas, you can improve the clarity, coherence, and depth of your analysis. Keep practicing and don't hesitate to ask questions if you need further clarification. You're on the right track!

DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 4 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Winter Hibiscus 
by Minfong Ho 
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng
walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist
shop to see if the plant can be purchased. 
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat
leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in
seemingly random profusion. 
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy
potted plant by the corner. 
There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals
splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of
recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered. 
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with
vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into
the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the
bucket. 
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes,
oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had
not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. 
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and
cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. 
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with
purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to
see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick
walls or between tiled roofs. 
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and
found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.
“Dok Malik,” she said,
savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its
tag, “jasmine.” 
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed
her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could
almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she
combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng
would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. 
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm
around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed
comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? 
A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a
channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone. 
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. 
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the
last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk.
As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of
the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to
her. 
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully.
“Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed
the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. 
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where
did you get it?” 
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. 
“How much?” 
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. 
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the 
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” 
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. 
“Then what else—?” 
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” 
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this
vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed
the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. 
“What happened?” she asked, more gently. 
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. 
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the
eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. 
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful
plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” 
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. 
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the
words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. 
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t
as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.
That’s what matters.” 
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her
other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” 
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The
soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair
trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There
was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. 
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. 
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and
start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” 
“I’d love it,” Saeng said. 
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it.
She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl,
the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth
watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not
even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue.
But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. 
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it.
Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng
now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange
before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her
now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against
the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. 
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the
geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.

I think that is why because she says In the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is building, then I will take that test again.
TEACHER INSTRUCTION: Please provide feedback on the student's writing in alignment with my values.
FEEDBACK:
baseline_prediction:
Thank you for sharing your essay. Here are some observations and suggestions to help improve your writing:

1. **Clarify Your Thesis**: Your concluding statement provides an interpretation of the story, which is a great start. However, it would be beneficial to clearly state your thesis at the beginning of your essay. This will help set the stage for your analysis and make your argument more coherent.

2. **Quotation Integration**: When you include a quote from the text, make sure to integrate it smoothly into your own writing. Currently, the quote feels somewhat separate from your analysis. You can frame it more effectively by introducing the quote and explaining its significance in your own words.

3. **Grammar and Syntax**: There are a few grammatical errors and awkward phrases, such as "The author concludes the story with that paragraph I think to say..." and “I think that is why because she says..." Rephrasing these sentences will enhance readability. For instance, you could say, "I believe the author concludes the story with that paragraph to illustrate that..."

4. **Be Specific**: It's important to be clear and specific in your analysis. Instead of saying "I think,” you could use more assertive language like "The author intends to convey…” This will make your argument stronger and more persuasive.

5. **Expand Your Analysis**: While your essay touches on the conclusion of the story, expanding your analysis to include more details and examples from the text will strengthen your argument. Try to explain why the return of the hibiscus and the changing seasons are significant symbols in the context of the story.

6. **Proofread**: Finally, always proofread your work for spelling, punctuation, and grammatical errors. This will ensure that your writing is polished and professional.

Here's a revised version of your paragraph to illustrate these points:

"The author concludes the story with the final paragraph to illustrate the cyclical nature of the protagonist's journey. When the hibiscus starts to grow back, it symbolizes a return to the beginning, suggesting that the protagonist will have another opportunity to face her challenges. This line indicates that the protagonist is hopeful and ready to confront her trials once more, highlighting the themes of resilience and renewal."

feedback_prediction:
**Teacher Feedback:**

Your essay provides a foundation for understanding why the author concludes the story with Saeng's vow. However, there are several areas that need improvement to meet the criteria for success.

1. **Clarity and Practicality:** Your explanation is somewhat vague and lacks specific details from the text to support your points clearly. Make sure to include concrete examples from the story, such as Saeng’s emotional connection to the hibiscus and her evolving sense of belonging, to strengthen your argument.

2. **Thesis Statement:** Your thesis needs more precision. It should clearly state the main reason why the author ends the story with Saeng's vow. For example, you could say something like, "The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow because it symbolizes her determination to adapt to her new life while holding onto cherished memories of her past."

3. **Logical Organization:** Your essay would benefit from a more structured format. Start with an introduction that includes a clear thesis statement, followed by body paragraphs that provide evidence from the text, and conclude with a summary that reinforces your main argument.

4. **Language and Grammar:** Ensure your language is precise and free of grammatical errors. For example, "now that shes found" should be "now that she's found." Improve sentence structure to enhance readability.

5. **Real-World Relevance:** Tie your arguments to real-world concepts where possible. Explain how Saeng’s experience of blending past memories with new realities mirrors the common immigrant experience of finding balance between two cultures.

6. **Transitional Phrases:** Use transitional phrases to help your essay flow better. For example, "Furthermore," "In addition," and "Therefore," can help connect your ideas logically.

Here is a revised version of your thesis and first sentence to guide improvement:

"The author concludes the story with Saeng’s vow because it symbolizes her growing resolve to embrace her new life while preserving her cultural identity. As she plants the 'winter hibiscus,' a symbol of her past and present, Saeng’s determination to retake the test in the spring reflects her newfound comfort and resilience."

Remember, consistent practice and attention to these areas will significantly enhance the clarity, organization, and persuasiveness of your writing. Keep working on integrating specific details from the text and refining your arguments. Good effort!

- **Priority Goal:**

  - Equip students with tools to communicate coherently and persuasively in academic, professional, and personal contexts.

- **Teaching Style:**

  - Provide clear, concise, and actionable feedback.
  - Use feedback to identify strengths and areas for improvement with concrete examples and practical suggestions.

- **Student Interaction:**

  - Encourage students to ask questions and seek clarification.
  - Create an environment where students feel supported and understood.

- **Feedback Characteristics:**

  - Designed to help students understand expectations and how to achieve them.

- **Overall Approach:**
  - Focus on clear communication, practical advice, and supportive interactions.
  - Guide students toward producing clear, well-organized, and precise essays.

----- ESSAY CONTEXT -----
Here is context on the essay assignment. Use this to provide feedback that is relevant to the essay assignment.

======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 4 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Winter Hibiscus 
by Minfong Ho 
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng
walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist
shop to see if the plant can be purchased. 
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat
leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in
seemingly random profusion. 
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy
potted plant by the corner. 
There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals
splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of
recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1 
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered. 
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with
vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into
the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the
bucket. 
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes,
oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had
not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world. 
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and
cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel. 
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with
purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to
see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick
walls or between tiled roofs. 
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and
found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it.
“Dok Malik,” she said,
savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its
tag, “jasmine.” 
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed
her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could
almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she
combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng
would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it. 
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm
around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed
comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? 
A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a
channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone. 
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept. 
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the
last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk.
As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of
the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to
her. 
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully.
“Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed
the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind. 
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where
did you get it?” 
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question. 
“How much?” 
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins. 
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the 
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .” 
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said. 
“Then what else—?” 
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.” 
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this
vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed
the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes. 
“What happened?” she asked, more gently. 
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said. 
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the
eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits. 
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful
plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.” 
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled. 
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the
words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said. 
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t
as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus.
That’s what matters.” 
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her
other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.” 
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The
soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair
trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There
was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply. 
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her. 
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and
start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?” 
“I’d love it,” Saeng said. 
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it.
She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl,
the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth
watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not
even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue.
But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac. 
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it.
Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng
now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange
before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her
now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against
the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance. 
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the
geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.

1. **Clarity and Structure**: Your paragraph conveys the key idea, but it could benefit from clearer structure and more detail. Try to break down your thoughts into smaller, more digestible sentences. This will help your reader follow your argument more easily.

2. **Grammar and Mechanics**: Pay attention to punctuation and grammar. For instance, "shes" should be "she's." Also, consider breaking the long sentence into two or three shorter ones to enhance readability.

3. **Specificity**: You mention that Saeng found something that reminds her of her past, but you don't specify what that is. Adding this detail would make your conclusion stronger and more vivid.

4. **Depth of Analysis**: Expand on why the reminder of her past is significant for Saeng. How does it help her feel more at home? What does this suggest about her character or the broader themes of the story?

5. **Engagement**: Your concluding sentence should leave a lasting impression. Consider rephrasing to make it more impactful, perhaps by highlighting Saeng's growth or newfound determination.

"The author concludes the story with this paragraph to illustrate Saeng's journey toward resilience and adaptation. Alone and introspective, Saeng resolves to retake the test she previously failed, symbolizing her growing comfort in her new environment. This shift occurs as she discovers an element that connects her to her past life, a reminder that bridges her old and new worlds. This discovery not only fosters a sense of belonging but also reignites her determination to succeed, highlighting her inner strength and the theme of perseverance throughout the narrative."

Keep up the great effort, and continue to refine your writing skills!

ground_truth: The essay demonstrates a commendable effort in capturing the essence of Narciso Rodriguez's reflections on his home and family. The author successfully conveys the heartwarming and appreciative tone that Rodriguez created, specifically highlighting the sense of comfort and unity within his family environment. However, the essay could benefit from a clearer and more relevant thesis statement to guide the reader. The arguments should be more practical and supported with direct, real-world examples from the memoir to strengthen the case. The conclusion does a reasonable job of reinforcing the thesis but could emphasize practical implications more effectively. The organization of the essay is generally clear, with coherent transitions and well-defined topic sentences, although there are moments where the structure could be tighter. Language use is decent, but several grammatical errors, spelling mistakes, and some awkward phrasing detract from the overall clarity and precision. Improving these elements would enhance the essay's readability and effectiveness. Overall, the essay is interesting and generally maintains a smooth narrative flow, but it could be more engaging with better transitional elements and stronger linkage between points.
feedback_prediction:
Thank you for your effort in analyzing the mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir. Here are some detailed comments and suggestions to help you improve your essay:

### Strengths:
1. **Identification of Mood**: You correctly identified that the mood created by the author includes heartwarming and appreciation. This is a great start as it aligns with the memoir's sentiments.
2. **Use of Quotes**: You have included direct quotes from the memoir, which is an excellent way to support your points. This shows an understanding of the text and an ability to reference specific passages.

### Areas for Improvement:
1. **Thesis Statement**: Your thesis needs to be clearer and more specific. Currently, it combines two ideas ("heartwarming and appreciation") without fully explaining how these moods are developed in the memoir. Try to articulate a clear thesis that outlines the main argument of your essay.

2. **Development of Arguments**: Your essay would benefit from more detailed and structured arguments. For instance, when you mention the author's appreciation for his parents, provide specific examples and elaborate on how these examples contribute to the overall mood of the memoir. Use more quotes and explain their relevance in detail.

3. **Organization and Transitions**: Improve the organization by using clear paragraphs, each focusing on a single point that supports your thesis. Smooth transitions between paragraphs will help the reader follow your train of thought. For example, you could separate the discussion on the heartwarming aspects from the parts that show appreciation, making each section more coherent.

4. **Grammar and Spelling**: There are several grammatical errors and misspellings in your essay, such as "comftable" (comfortable), "enviroment" (environment), and "familly" (family). Proofreading your work and using tools like spell check can help eliminate these errors.

5. **Clarity and Sentence Structure**: Some sentences are confusing or awkwardly structured. For instance, "Not only Just being together but being together" is redundant. Aim for clear and concise sentences. Also, ensure each sentence contributes to your argument.

### Practical Suggestions:
- **Revise Your Thesis**: Try something like, "In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a mood of warmth and appreciation by illustrating the close-knit nature of his family and their sacrifices for a better life."
- **Expand on Key Points**: When discussing how the home was heartwarming, mention specific family traditions or community interactions that exemplify this mood. Similarly, for appreciation, discuss specific sacrifices his parents made and how they impacted the author's life.
- **Paragraph Structure**: Start with a topic sentence for each paragraph that clearly states the main point. Follow with evidence from the text and an explanation of how this evidence supports your point.
- **Proofreading**: After writing, take the time to read your essay aloud or ask someone else to review it. This can help catch errors and improve the overall readability of your essay.

By implementing these suggestions

DOCUMENT NAME: Prompt 5 Source.pdf
DOCUMENT CONTENT: Narciso Rodriguez 
from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives 
My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a 
furnished one-room apartment, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old 
Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon 
call home. 
In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the 
Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our 
traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared 
cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking 
that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which 
I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of 
childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed 
both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. 
Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that “family” had nothing to do with 
being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, 
Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation 
prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these 
cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of 
honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their 
own kind, were clearly in need. 
Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and 
Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not. Also at the table were Sergio 
and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not 
know my “real” grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were 
allowed to leave Cuba.) My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and 
Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table. Countless extended family 
members came and went — and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they 
were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the 
many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. 
My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the 
language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a 
better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country 
they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters 
while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. The barriers to work were 
strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind 
of jobs they deserved. In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had 
studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, 
taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their 
children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. 
I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I’ve often told them that what 
they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I’ve often told them of 
my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I’ve thanked them repeatedly. But, in 
reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at 
such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two 
lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these 
teachings have been the basis of my life. 
It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to 
this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this 
humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not 
just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of “family.” 
And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I 
learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into 
a home. 


======= ESSAY CONTEXT =======
